choices: BOTH translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text.
TRANSLATION 1
YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.

text: I chose T1 for the first sentence. T2 omits the detail about the coffee and grease on the back of the photo (which doesn't significantly change the meaning but it's still in the source text), and the way that first sentence has been rearranged works well. The clause in T2, "browned and stained on the back by the fingers of all those who had held them at other meals," is unwieldy.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: De main en main passaient des photos brunies au dos taché par tous les doigts qui les avaient tenues dans d’autres repas, mélange de café et de graisse fondu en une couleur indéfinissable. Dans les mariés raides et graves, les invités de la noce s’étageant sur plusieurs rangs le long d’un mur, on ne reconnaissait ni ses parents ni personne. Ce n’était pas soi non plus qu’on voyait dans le bébé de sexe indistinct à demi nu sur un coussin mais quelqu’un d’autre, une créature appartenant à un temps muet et inaccessible.
data.target: Darkened photos passed from hand to hand, the backs soiled by all the other fingers that had handled them at other meals, coffee and fat dissolved into an indefinable hue. No one recognized their parents—or anyone, come to that—in the stiff and somber newlyweds, the wedding guests in tiered rows along a wall. Nor did one see oneself in the half-naked baby of indistinct sex, who sat on a cushion, an alien creature from a mute and inaccessible time
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: From hand to hand were passed photographs, their backs stained with the grease and coffee of many meals, a mixture of colors that defied definition. In the stiff and solemn wedding-party, the guests ranged in several rows along a wall, one could not recognize either one's parents or anyone else. Nor could one recognize oneself in the half-naked, sexless baby on the cushion, but rather someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

From hand to hand were passed photographs, their backs stained with the grease and coffee of many meals, a mixture of colors that defied definition. In the stiff and solemn wedding-party, the guests ranged in several rows along a wall, one could not recognize either one's parents or anyone else. Nor could one recognize oneself in the half-naked, sexless baby on the cushion, but rather someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.


########


TRANSLATION 2:

Photos, browned and stained on the back by the fingers of all those who had held them at other meals, passed from hand to hand. In the stiff and serious wedding-party, the guests arranged in several rows along a wall, one could not recognize either one's parents or anyone else. Nor was it oneself that one saw in the half-naked, sexless baby on a cushion, but someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.

In the stiff and solemn wedding-party, the guests ranged in several rows along a wall, one could not recognize either one's parents or anyone else. Nor could one recognize oneself in the half-naked, sexless baby on the cushion, but rather someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.

Nor was it oneself that one saw in the half-naked, sexless baby on a cushion, but someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 2
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text: Both translations made a lot of the same errors, but T1 was much less natural: "the threats of drink" vs "the threat of alcohol (or drink)," using a ruler to "tap on the fingers" vs "rap on (their) knuckles," "without trips outside the regiment" vs "no travels outside of the regiment." The translation of "avaient accédé" in T1 added "been able to" (in addition to using the wrong verb given the context, "access"). T2 wasn't right either, but at least it wasn't as awkward or clunky and the spirit remained somewhat truer in my opinion.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Récit familial et récit social c’est tout un. Les voix des convives délimitaient les espaces de la jeunesse : la campagne et les fermes où, de mémoire perdue, les hommes avaient été commis et les filles servantes, l’usine où tous s’étaient rencontrés, fréquentés et mariés, les petits commerces où avaient accédé les plus ambitieux. Elles dessinaient des histoires sans événements personnels autres que les naissances, les mariages et les deuils, sans voyages en dehors du régiment dans une lointaine ville de garnison, des existences occupées par le travail, sa dureté et son usure, les menaces de la boisson. L’école était un arrière-fond mythique, un bref âge d’or dont l’Instituteur avait été le dieu rude avec sa règle en fer pour taper sur les doigts.
data.target: Family narrative and social narrative are one and the same. The voices around the table mapped out the territories of youth: countrysides and farms where, for time immemorial, men had been hired hands and girls housemaids; the factory where they all had met, stepped out together, and married, the small businesses to which the most ambitious had risen. They told stories that contained no personal detail except for births, weddings, and funerals, no travel except to regiments in distant garrison towns, existences entirely filled by work, its harsh conditions, the perils of drink. School was a mythical backdrop, a brief golden age with the schoolmaster as its rough god, equipped with an iron ruler for the rapping of knuckles.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: Family stories and social stories are one and the same. The voices of the guests outlined the spaces of youth: the countryside and the farms where, in forgotten memory, the men had been hired hands and the girls servants, the factory where they had all met, courted and married, the small businesses where the most ambitious had been able to access. They described stories without personal events other than births, marriages and deaths, without trips outside the regiment to a distant garrison town, lives occupied by work, its harshness and its weariness, the threats of drink. School was a mythical background, a brief golden age of which the teacher had been the harsh god with his iron ruler to tap on the fingers.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

Family stories and social stories are one and the same. The voices of the guests outlined the spaces of youth: the countryside and the farms where, in forgotten memory, the men had been hired hands and the girls servants, the factory where they had all met, courted and married, the small businesses where the most ambitious had been able to access. They described stories without personal events other than births, marriages and deaths, without trips outside the regiment to a distant garrison town, lives occupied by work, its harshness and its weariness, the threats of drink. School was a mythical background, a brief golden age of which the teacher had been the harsh god with his iron ruler to tap on the fingers.


########


TRANSLATION 2:

Family stories and social stories were one and the same. The voices of the guests outlined the spaces of their youth: the countryside and the farms where, from time immemorial, the men had been hired hands and the girls servants, the factory where they had all met, courted and married, the small businesses to which the most ambitious had aspired. They drew stories with no personal events other than births, marriages and deaths, no travels outside of the regiment to a distant garrison town, lives occupied by work, its hardness and its weariness, the threat of alcohol. School was a mythical background, a brief golden age of which the teacher had been the stern god with his iron ruler to rap on the knuckles.

They described stories without personal events other than births, marriages and deaths, without trips outside the regiment to a distant garrison town, lives occupied by work, its harshness and its weariness, the threats of drink. School was a mythical background, a brief golden age of which the teacher had been the harsh god with his iron ruler to tap on the fingers.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 2
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text:
Both translations, T1 and T2, made some similar mistakes - I believe the Cirque Bouglione should be left untranslated as it is a famous circus, Notre Dame de Boulogne should also probably remain in French, and "accompany" for "reconduire" omits the "re-" aspect of the verb (aspectual prefix), indicating that the statue is returning, which is obvious more joyous than some new statue arriving.
I chose T2 for two instances that it was clearly superior:
- "the world was full of the desires to be satisfied on the spot" is much more accurate and evocative than "there were a lot of desires that needed to be satisfied right away"
- "standing on the roof-rack" is more accurate and actually makes sense, as opposed to "perched on the roof of the luggage rack" - luggage racks generally don't have roofs

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: La frénésie qui avait suivi la Libération s’estompait. Alors les gens ne pensaient qu’à sortir et le monde était plein de désirs à satisfaire sur-le-champ. Tout ce qui constituait la première fois depuis la guerre provoquait la ruée, les bananes, les billets de la Loterie nationale, le feu d’artifice. Par quartiers entiers, de la grand-mère soutenue par ses filles au nourrisson en landau, les gens se précipitaient à la fête foraine, à la retraite aux flambeaux, au cirque Bouglione où ils manquaient être piétinés dans la bousculade. Ils se portaient en foule priante et chantante sur la route pour accueillir la statue de Notre-Dame de Boulogne et la reconduire le lendemain sur des kilomètres. Profane ou religieuse, toute occasion leur était bonne d’être au-dehors ensemble, comme s’ils voulaient continuer de vivre collectivement. Le dimanche soir, les cars revenaient de la mer avec de grands jeunes gens en short qui chantaient à tue-tête, grimpés sur le toit à bagages. Les chiens se promenaient en liberté et s’accouplaient au milieu de la rue.
data.target: The frenzy that had followed Liberation was fading. All that people thought about was going out, and the world was full of desires that clamored for immediate satisfaction. Anything that comprised a first time since the war provoked a stampede—bananas, fireworks, National Lottery tickets. Entire neighborhoods, from elderly ladies propped up by their daughters to infants in strollers, flocked to the funfair, the torchlight tattoo, and the Bouglione circus, where they narrowly escaped being crushed in the melee. They took to the road in praying, singing crowds to welcome the statue of Our Lady of Boulogne and walk her back the following day over many kilometers. They never missed a chance, secular or religious, to be outside with other people, as if they still yearned to live in a group. On Sunday evenings, the coaches returned from the seaside with tall youths in shorts clinging to the luggage roofs and singing at the top of their voices. Dogs roamed free and mated in the middle of the streets.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: The frenzy that had followed Liberation was beginning to ebb. People were only thinking of getting out and the world was full of desires to be satisfied on the spot. Anything that marked the first time since the war set off a stampede, bananas, national lottery tickets, fireworks. Entire neighborhoods, from grandmothers supported by their daughters to babies in prams, rushed to the funfair, the torchlight parade, the Bouglione circus, where they were almost trampled in the crush. They thronged in their thousands, praying and singing, along the road to welcome the statue of Our Lady of Boulogne and accompany it the next day for miles. Whether it was a secular or religious occasion, they were all eager to be outside together, as if they wanted to keep living collectively. On Sunday evenings the coaches came back from the sea with tall young men in shorts singing at the top of their voices, standing on the roof-rack. Dogs roamed free and mated in the middle of the street.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

The frenzy that had followed liberation was beginning to die down. Now people just wanted to get out and there were a lot of desires that needed to be satisfied right away. Anything that was a first since the war caused a rush, like bananas, lottery tickets, and fireworks. Entire neighborhoods, from grandmothers supported by their daughters to babies in prams, rushed to the fair, the torchlight parade, and Bouglione's circus, where they almost got trampled in the stampede. They went in a praying and singing crowd to the road to welcome the statue of Our Lady of Boulogne and accompany it the next day for miles. Whether it was secular or religious, any occasion was good enough for them to be outside together, as if they wanted to keep living collectively. Sunday night, the buses came back from the sea with tall young people in shorts singing at the top of their lungs, perched on the roof of the luggage rack. Dogs roamed freely and mated in the middle of the street.


########


TRANSLATION 2:

The frenzy that had followed Liberation was beginning to ebb. People were only thinking of getting out and the world was full of desires to be satisfied on the spot. Anything that marked the first time since the war set off a stampede, bananas, national lottery tickets, fireworks. Entire neighborhoods, from grandmothers supported by their daughters to babies in prams, rushed to the funfair, the torchlight parade, the Bouglione circus, where they were almost trampled in the crush. They thronged in their thousands, praying and singing, along the road to welcome the statue of Our Lady of Boulogne and accompany it the next day for miles. Whether it was a secular or religious occasion, they were all eager to be outside together, as if they wanted to keep living collectively. On Sunday evenings the coaches came back from the sea with tall young men in shorts singing at the top of their voices, standing on the roof-rack. Dogs roamed free and mated in the middle of the street.

Dogs roamed free and mated in the middle of the street.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 2
YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.

text:
Both translations made the same mistranslations. I chose T2 for some choices that made the text easier to read and more natural. For example:
- "the episodes of which they would not be able to arrange for a long time yet" vs "which they would not be able to organize the episodes of for a long time" (the second is not grammatically correct, though it is how people talk)
- "They regretted not having been born, or at least only just" vs "They regretted not having been born, or barely" (the second is much less clear, "barely born" is quite awkward)

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Les enfants n’écoutaient pas et se dépêchaient de quitter la table dès qu’ils en avaient reçu la permission, profitant de la bienveillance générale des jours de fête pour se livrer aux jeux interdits, sauter sur les lits et faire de la balançoire la tête en bas. Mais ils retenaient tout. À côté du temps fabuleux — dont ils n’ordonneraient pas avant longtemps les épisodes, la Débâcle, l’Exode, l’Occupation, le Débarquement, la Victoire — ils trouvaient terne celui, sans nom, où ils grandissaient. Ils regrettaient de ne pas avoir été nés, ou à peine, quand il fallait partir en cohorte sur les routes et dormir sur la paille comme des bohémiens. De ce temps non vécu ils garderaient le regret tenace. La mémoire des autres leur refilait une nostalgie secrète pour cette époque qu’ils avaient manquée de si peu et l’espérance de la vivre un jour.
data.target: The children didn’t listen. They rushed from the table the moment they were excused and took advantage of the holiday goodwill to play forbidden games, jumping on beds, swinging upside down. But they remembered every detail. Next to that wondrous time, the episodes whose order they would not retain for years, the Rout, the Occupation, the Exodus, the Landing, the Victory, the nameless time in which they grew seemed colorless. They regretted they had not been born (or were only infants) in the days when people were forced to take to the roads in bands and sleep on straw like gypsies. Not having lived this way would stamp them with a lasting sorrow. They were saddled with other people’s memories and a secret nostalgia for the time they’d missed by so little, along with the hope of living it one day.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: The children paid no attention and were eager to leave the table as soon as they were given permission, taking advantage of the general benevolence of the holiday to indulge in forbidden games, jumping on the beds and swinging upside down. But they remembered everything. Next to the fabulous time—which they would not be able to organize the episodes of for a long time, the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory—they found the one without a name, in which they were growing up, to be dull. They regretted not having been born, or barely, when it was necessary to leave in a cohort on the roads and sleep on straw like gypsies. They would keep a persistent regret for this time they had not lived. The memory of others passed on to them a secret nostalgia for this era that they had missed by so little and the hope of living it one day.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

The children paid no attention and were eager to leave the table as soon as they were given permission, taking advantage of the general benevolence of the holiday to indulge in forbidden games, jumping on the beds and swinging upside down. But they remembered everything. Next to the fabulous time—which they would not be able to organize the episodes of for a long time, the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory—they found the one without a name, in which they were growing up, to be dull. They regretted not having been born, or barely, when it was necessary to leave in a cohort on the roads and sleep on straw like gypsies. They would keep a persistent regret for this time they had not lived. The memory of others passed on to them a secret nostalgia for this era that they had missed by so little and the hope of living it one day.


########


TRANSLATION 2:

The children paid no attention and, as soon as they were allowed, they hurried away from the table, taking advantage of the general good-will of the holiday to indulge in forbidden games, jumping on the beds and swinging upside down. But they remembered everything. Beside the fabulous time—the episodes of which they would not be able to arrange for a long time yet—the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory—they found the nameless one in which they were growing up dull. They regretted not having been born, or at least only just, when it was necessary to set out in a cohort on the roads and sleep on straw like gypsies. They would keep a tenacious regret for this time they had missed by so little, and the memory of the others would pass on to them a secret nostalgia for this epoch and the hope of living it one day.

But they remembered everything. Next to the fabulous time—which they would not be able to organize the episodes of for a long time, the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory—they found the one without a name, in which they were growing up, to be dull. They regretted not having been born, or barely, when it was necessary to leave in a cohort on the roads and sleep on straw like gypsies. They would keep a persistent regret for this time they had not lived. The memory of others passed on to them a secret nostalgia for this era that they had missed by so little and the hope of living it one day.

But they remembered everything. Beside the fabulous time—the episodes of which they would not be able to arrange for a long time yet—the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory—they found the nameless one in which they were growing up dull. They regretted not having been born, or at least only just, when it was necessary to set out in a cohort on the roads and sleep on straw like gypsies. They would keep a tenacious regret for this time they had missed by so little, and the memory of the others would pass on to them a secret nostalgia for this epoch and the hope of living it one day.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 1
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text: Both translations are mostly correct, but T2 took too much poetic license with the first sentence (nowhere in the source does it mention the "present war," the war they are comparing to could be a past war as well). Also the phrase "of the bells of the 11th of November 1918" is much clunkier than "of the bells of November 11, 1918," and "had not even had a bomb dropped on their heads" sounds more odd in English than the phrase in the source.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Ils embrayaient par comparaison sur la guerre d’avant, la Grande, celle de 14, gagnée, elle, dans le sang et la gloire, une guerre d’hommes que les femmes de la table écoutaient avec respect. Ils parlaient du Chemin des Dames et de Verdun, des gazés, des cloches du 11 novembre 1918. Ils nommaient des villages dont pas un enfant parti au front n’était revenu. Ils opposaient les soldats dans la boue des tranchées aux prisonniers de 40, au chaud et à l’abri pendant cinq ans, qui n’avaient même pas reçu de bombes sur la tête. Ils se disputaient l’héroïsme et le malheur.
data.target: They started to make comparisons with the other war, 1914, the Great War, won in blood and glory, a man’s war, and around the table the women listened to the men with respect. They spoke of Chemin des Dames and Verdun, the gassed soldiers, the bells of November 11, 1918. They named villages whose children left for the Front, never to return, not one. They compared the soldiers in the mud-filled trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and sheltered for five years without a bomb ever landing on them. They quarreled over who had been more heroic and who more unlucky.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: They compared it with the previous war, the Great War of 1914, which had been won in blood and glory, a war of men that the women at the table listened to with respect. They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of November 11, 1918. They mentioned villages from which no child who had gone to the front had ever returned. They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and safe for five years, who had not even been bombed. They argued about heroism and misfortune.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

They compared it with the previous war, the Great War of 1914, which had been won in blood and glory, a war of men that the women at the table listened to with respect. They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of November 11, 1918. They mentioned villages from which no child who had gone to the front had ever returned. They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and safe for five years, who had not even been bombed. They argued about heroism and misfortune.


########


TRANSLATION 2:

They then compared the present war with the Great War of 1914, won in blood and glory, a war of men which the women at the table listened to with respect. They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of the 11th of November 1918. They named villages from which not one child who had gone to the front had returned. They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and safe for five years, who had not even had a bomb dropped on their heads. They argued about heroism and misfortune.

They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of November 11, 1918. They mentioned villages from which no child who had gone to the front had ever returned. They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and safe for five years, who had not even been bombed. They argued about heroism and misfortune.

They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of the 11th of November 1918. They named villages from which not one child who had gone to the front had returned. They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and safe for five years, who had not even had a bomb dropped on their heads. They argued about heroism and misfortune.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 1
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text:
Both translations made the glaring error of mistranslating "en mangeant et buvant" as "through eating and drinking" and "by eating and drinking," respectively (it should be "while eating and drinking). But T2 had other errors as well, and the transitions between sentences aren't right - it seems the sentences were individually translated without considering what they meant in relation to one another.
T1 was very clearly superior.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Mais ils ne parlaient que de ce qu’ils avaient vu, qui pouvait se revivre en mangeant et buvant. Ils n’avaient pas assez de talent ou de conviction pour parler de ce qu’ils savaient mais qu’ils n’avaient pas vu. Donc ni des enfants juifs montant dans des trains pour Auschwitz, ni des morts de faim ramassés au matin dans le ghetto de Varsovie, ni des 10 000 degrés à Hiroshima. D’où cette impression que les cours d’histoire, les documentaires et les films, plus tard, ne dissiperaient pas : ni les fours crématoires ni la bombe atomique ne se situaient dans la même époque que le beurre au marché noir, les alertes et les descentes à la cave.
data.target: But they only spoke of what they had seen and could re-live while eating and drinking. They lacked the talent and conviction to speak of things they’d been aware of but had not seen. Therefore, no Jewish children boarding trains for Auschwitz, nor bodies of starvation victims collected every morning from the Warsaw Ghetto, nor Hiroshima’s 10,000 degrees. Whence our impression, which later history courses, documentaries, and films failed to dispel, that neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb belonged to the same timeline as black market butter, air-raid warnings, and descents to the cellar.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: But they only talked about what they had seen, which could be relived by eating and drinking. They lacked the talent or the conviction to talk about what they knew but had not seen. Therefore, neither the Jewish children boarding the trains to Auschwitz, nor the starving dead picked up in the morning from the Warsaw ghetto, nor the 10,000 degrees at Hiroshima. This was the impression that history classes, documentaries and films later would not dispel: neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb were in the same era as the black market butter, the air-raid sirens and the descents into the cellar.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

But they only spoke of what they had seen, which could be relived through eating and drinking. They lacked the talent or the conviction to talk about what they knew but had not seen. So there was no mention of Jewish children boarding trains to Auschwitz, of the dead of hunger picked up in the morning in the Warsaw ghetto, or of the 10,000 degrees at Hiroshima. Hence the impression that history classes, documentaries and films later on would not dispel: neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb belonged to the same era as the black market butter, the air raid sirens and the trips to the cellar.


########


TRANSLATION 2:

But they only talked about what they had seen, which could be relived by eating and drinking. They lacked the talent or the conviction to talk about what they knew but had not seen. Therefore, neither the Jewish children boarding the trains to Auschwitz, nor the starving dead picked up in the morning from the Warsaw ghetto, nor the 10,000 degrees at Hiroshima. This was the impression that history classes, documentaries and films later would not dispel: neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb were in the same era as the black market butter, the air-raid sirens and the descents into the cellar.
data.text1: But they only spoke of what they had seen, which could be relived through eating and drinking. They lacked the talent or the conviction to talk about what they knew but had not seen. So there was no mention of Jewish children boarding trains to Auschwitz, of the dead of hunger picked up in the morning in the Warsaw ghetto, or of the 10,000 degrees at Hiroshima. Hence the impression that history classes, documentaries and films later on would not dispel: neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb belonged to the same era as the black market butter, the air raid sirens and the trips to the cellar.
data.text2: But they only talked about what they had seen, which could be relived by eating and drinking. They lacked the talent or the conviction to talk about what they knew but had not seen. Therefore, neither the Jewish children boarding the trains to Auschwitz, nor the starving dead picked up in the morning from the Warsaw ghetto, nor the 10,000 degrees at Hiroshima. This was the impression that history classes, documentaries and films later would not dispel: neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb were in the same era as the black market butter, the air-raid sirens and the descents into the cellar.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 2
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text:
Both translations are awkward and make the same errors. If this is meant to be US English, "Fortnight" isn't really appropriate and commas should be on the inside of quotation marks. "Camarades" should be "classmates" or "friends," not "comrades. Other places where they were too literal - "the circus of last year" instead of "last year's circus," "the streets of the center" instead of "city center" or something similar, "the slopes/sides of the hills" instead of "the hillsides." Both translated "le Club des Chansonniers" which should've been left as it's the title of the broadcast and didn't translate "Crochet" (a type of radio talent show) or "Quitte ou double" (Double or nothing). Both had the ridiculous clause "Between the fair and the fair."
I chose T2 because it had fewer mistranslations than T1, as you can see in the annotations.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Sous l’immuabilité, les affiches du cirque de l’année dernière avec la photo de Roger Lanzac, les images de première communion distribuées aux camarades, le Club des Chansonniers sur Radio Luxembourg, les jours se remplissaient de désirs nouveaux. Le dimanche après-midi, on s’agglutinait à la vitrine du magasin d’électricité générale devant la télévision. Des cafés investissaient dans l’achat d’un poste pour attirer la clientèle. Au flanc des collines serpentaient des pistes de motocross et l’on regardait monter et descendre les engins assourdissants la journée entière. L’impatience grandissante du commerce avec ses nouveaux mots d’ordre, « initiative », « dynamisme », secouait le train-train des villes. Entre la fête foraine et la kermesse, la Quinzaine commerciale s’installait comme rite de printemps. Dans les rues du centre, les haut-parleurs beuglaient des incitations à acheter, entrecoupées de chansons d’Annie Cordy et d’Eddie Constantine, pour gagner la Simca ou la salle à manger. Sur le podium, place de la Mairie, un animateur local faisait rire avec les blagues de Roger Nicolas et de Jean Richard, rameutait des candidats pour le Crochet ou Quitte ou double, comme à la radio. Assise dans un coin du podium trônait sous sa couronne la Reine du Commerce. La marchandise avançait sous les couleurs de la fête. Les gens disaient « ça change » ou « il ne faut pas s’encroûter, on s’abrutit à rester chez soi ».
data.target: Beneath the surface of the things that never changed, last year’s circus posters with the photo of Roger Lanzac, First Communion photos handed out to schoolmates, the Club des chansonniers on Radio Luxembourg, our days swelled with new desires. On Sunday afternoons, we crowded around the windows of the general electrics shop to watch television. Cafés invested in TV sets to lure clientele. Motocross trails wound up and down the hills, and we watched the deafening machines race all day. Commerce grew increasingly impatient and galvanized the daily routine of towns and cities with new watchwords such as “initiative” and “dynamism.” The two-week trade fair became a fixture among the more traditional rites of spring, the funfair and the church bazaar. Loudspeakers bellowed sales pitches through the streets of the town center, interspersed with songs by Annie Cordy and Eddie Constantine. Buy, we were urged, to get a chance to win a Simca or a dining room suite. From the podium in front of the town hall, a local presenter entertained the crowd with the jokes of Roger Nicolas and Jean Richard, and rounded up candidates for quiz shows, The Hook or Double or Nothing, as on the radio. From a corner of the podium, the Queen of Commerce ruled from beneath her crown. The world of merchandise took advantage of the holiday to stake its claim. People said, “Gets you out of the house,” and “It’s a nice change, you don’t want be an old stick-in-the-mud.”
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: Under the immutability, the posters of the circus of last year with the photo of Roger Lanzac, the first communion images distributed to the comrades, the Club of Songwriters on Radio Luxembourg, the days were filled with new desires. On Sunday afternoons, people crowded around the window of the general electrical store in front of the television. Cafes invested in the purchase of a set to attract customers. On the sides of the hills, motocross tracks snaked and one could watch the deafening machines go up and down all day. The growing impatience of commerce with its new watchwords, "initiative", "dynamism", shook the daily routine of the cities. Between the fair and the fair, the Commercial Fortnight was installed as a rite of spring. In the streets of the center, loudspeakers blared out calls to buy, interspersed with songs by Annie Cordy and Eddie Constantine, to win the Simca or the dining room. On the podium, in the Place de la Mairie, a local presenter made people laugh with the jokes of Roger Nicolas and Jean Richard, rounded up candidates for the Crochet or Quitte ou double, as on the radio. Seated in a corner of the podium, the Queen of Commerce reigned under her crown. Merchandise advanced under the colors of the party. People said "it's changing" or "you can't get stuck, you get stupid staying at home."

choices: TRANSLATION 2 adds or omits information that significantly change the meaning of the text.
TRANSLATION 1
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text: T1's big issue was changing "les enveloppait" from active to passive, and "tunic" is certainly less accurate than "jacket." But T2 seemed to be trying to localize the text for the US, using "army" instead of "regiment" and "draft board" instead of "conscription review," neither of which are actually accurate translations. T2 also mistranslated "embrasser" as "hug" instead of "kiss," in addition to leaving out the detail of "standing on tiptoe," changing the image from a soldier receiving a farewell kiss from his sweetheart to a soldier possibly getting a hug from mom. The idea of being grown men is completely lost and this change in imagery completely alters the mood of the rest of the paragraph.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Les garçons étaient fiers de partir au régiment et on les trouvait beaux en soldats. Le soir du conseil de révision, ils faisaient la tournée des cafés pour célébrer la gloire d’être reconnus comme de vrais hommes. Avant le régiment, ils étaient encore des gamins et ne valaient rien sur le marché du travail et du mariage. Après, ils pourraient avoir une femme et des enfants. L’uniforme qu’ils promenaient dans le quartier lors des permissions les enveloppait de beauté patriotique et de sacrifice virtuel. L’ombre des combattants vainqueurs, des GI, flottait autour d’eux. Le drap rêche de la vareuse, effleurée quand on se hissait sur la pointe des pieds pour les embrasser, matérialisait la coupure absolue entre l’univers des hommes et celui des femmes. À les voir on éprouvait un sentiment d’héroïsme.
data.target: Boys were proud to leave for their military service. We thought they looked handsome in their uniforms. On recruitment night, they made the rounds of the cafés to celebrate. It brought them glory to be recognized as real men. Before military service, they were still considered kids, devoid of status in the labor or marriage market. Afterwards, they could have a wife and children. The uniform they paraded through the neighborhood when they were on furlough lent them an aura of beauty and virtual sacrifice. The shadow of the victorious veterans, the GIs, hovered over them. The rough cloth of the jacket we brushed against as we stretched up to kiss them made tangible the absolute division between the worlds of men and women. When we looked at them we had a sense of heroism.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: The boys were proud to go to the army and they looked handsome in their uniforms. On the night of the draft board, they went around the bars to celebrate their glory of being recognized as real men. Before the army, they were still kids and were worth nothing in the job and marriage market. After, they could have a wife and children. The uniform they wore around the neighborhood on leave enveloped them in patriotic beauty and virtual sacrifice. The shadow of victorious fighters, GIs, hovered around them. The rough fabric of the jacket, brushed when they were hugged, materialized the absolute cut between the world of men and that of women. Seeing them, one felt a sense of heroism.
data.merged:
TRANSLATION 1:

The boys were proud to be leaving for the regiment and they looked handsome in their uniforms. On the night of their conscription review they went around the bars to celebrate the glory of being recognized as real men. Before the regiment they had been just kids and worth nothing in the job or marriage market. Afterwards they could have a wife and children. The uniform they wore around the neighborhood on leave was wrapped in patriotic beauty and virtual sacrifice. The shadow of victorious fighters, GIs, floated around them. The rough cloth of the tunic, brushed when you stood on tiptoe to kiss them, materialized the absolute break between the world of men and that of women. Seeing them gave one a feeling of heroism.


########

The rough fabric of the jacket, brushed when they were hugged, materialized the absolute cut between the world of men and that of women. Seeing them, one felt a sense of heroism.

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
TRANSLATION 2
NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.

text: While the two translations are almost identical, both mistranslating "boudinée" and "jupe à bretelles" in the same way, but there were two glaring errors in T1: the "pinafore" "pulled up in front" vs. rising up in front ("pulled up" sounds more active, as though it's done intentionally), and the carved table "now fully visible" - "now" is not in the original text.

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Une autre photo, signée du même photographe — mais le papier du livret est plus ordinaire et le liseré d’or a disparu —, sans doute vouée à la même distribution familiale, montre une petite fille d’environ quatre ans, sérieuse, presque triste malgré une bonne bouille rebondie sous des cheveux courts, séparés par une raie au milieu et tirés en arrière par des barrettes auxquelles sont attachés des rubans, comme des papillons. La main gauche repose sur la même table sculptée, entièrement visible, de style Louis XVI. Elle apparaît boudinée dans son corsage, sa jupe à bretelles remonte par-devant à cause d’un ventre proéminent, peut-être signe de rachitisme (1944, environ).
data.target: Another photo, stamped by the same photographer—the folder is of lesser quality, the gold border has disappeared—and probably destined for the same distribution within the family, shows a little girl of about four, serious, almost sad despite her nice plump face under short hair, parted down the middle and pulled back with barrettes to which little bow-ties are attached, like butterflies. Her left hand rests on the same carved Louis XVI–style table, which is fully visible. She bulges out of her bodice, her skirt with shoulder straps hiked up a little over a protuberant belly, possibly a sign of rickets (circa 1944).
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: Another photograph, signed by the same photographer—but the paper of the booklet is more ordinary and the gilt edging has disappeared—no doubt destined for the same family distribution, shows a little girl of about four years old, serious, almost sad despite a good round face beneath short hair, parted in the middle and pulled back with barrettes to which are attached ribbons, like butterflies. Her left hand rests on the same carved table, now fully visible, in the Louis XVI style. She appears plump in her bodice, her pinafore pulled up in front because of a prominent belly, perhaps a sign of rickets (around 1944).

choices: NEITHER of the translations add or omit information that significantly change the meaning of the text
YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
TRANSLATION 1

text: These are very close. T1 mistranslated "à pinces" and missed that the flower topped the wall and weren't all around it, but T2 left out the flounces on her dress and I think T1's "mischievously" and "nonchalant" are more accurate than "playfully" and "relaxed."

data.author: annie_ernaux
data.source: Deux autres petites photos à bords dentelés, datant vraisemblablement de la même année, montrent la même enfant, mais plus menue, dans une robe à volants et manches ballon. Sur la première, elle se blottit de façon espiègle contre une femme au corps massif, d’un seul tenant dans une robe à larges rayures, les cheveux relevés en gros rouleaux. Sur l’autre, elle lève le poing gauche, le droit est retenu par la main d’un homme, grand, en veste claire et pantalon à pinces, à la posture nonchalante. Les deux photos ont été prises le même jour devant un muret surmonté d’une bordure de fleurs, dans une cour pavée. Au-dessus des têtes passe une corde à linge sur laquelle une épingle est restée accrochée.
data.target: Two other small photos with serrated edges, very likely taken the same year, show the same child, slimmer, in a flounced dress with puff sleeves. In the first one, she nestles playfully against a stout woman, whose body is a solid mass in a wide-striped dress, her hair swept up in two big buns. In the other photo, the child’s left hand is raised, fist closed, the right one held back by the hand of a man. He is tall with a light-colored jacket and pleated trousers, his bearing nonchalant. Both photos were taken on the same day in a cobbled courtyard, in front of a low wall with a floral border along the top. A clothesline hangs above their heads, a clothespin still hooked over it.
data.davinci003_para_sent_tag: Two other small, scalloped-edge photos, probably taken in the same year, show the same child, but smaller, in a dress with puffy sleeves. In the first, she playfully cuddles up to a woman with a solid body, dressed in a wide-striped dress, her hair in big curls. In the second, she raises her left fist, her right hand held by a tall man in a light jacket and pleated trousers, in a relaxed pose. The two photos were taken on the same day in front of a wall topped with a flower border, in a paved courtyard. Above their heads a clothesline passes, with a clothespin still attached.

In the first she is mischievously snuggling up to a woman with a solid body, wearing a dress with wide stripes, her hair in big curls. In the second she is raising her left fist, her right being held by a tall man in a light jacket and pinstriped trousers, with a nonchalant air. The two photographs were taken on the same day in front of a wall with a flower border, in a paved courtyard. Above their heads a clothesline passes, with a pin still hooked on it.
